review_blob: My favourite American beer.  It's cold, clean, and actually seems to have a premium status in the UK (which I don't think it deserves).  It's clean, clear, easy to drink and inoffensive.  Better than drinking pints of Fosters....
Pilsner.  Probably overshadowed by Budvar, but Staropramen is easier to get on draught in the UK.  Can be quite dry and musty when served in the average English town centre pub.

4.5% ABV doesn't sound accurate.  3.5%b might be more like it.  McEwans 70/- is basically standard "heavy" in Scottish pubs.  A bit like standard English bitter but frankly (as a Scot) I'd drink John Smith's Smooth before McEwan's 70/-.  McEwan's gets intersting when you start to look at the strong ales like 80/-, 90/- and Champion.

It strikes me that Koelsch is a very lager-y type of beer.  Clean taste, nothing challenging.  However, on a recent business trip to Cologne I was impressed with how easily the Sion Koelsch slid down my throat.  Not really surprised thate reviewers from other areas of Germany pour scorn on Sion - as a very light beir it's understandable that they don't like it.  Me, on the other hand - I thought that it was the perfect beer to unwind after a flight on a very stressful business trip.  Koln has its own culture and beer, and that's something to admire.  Who can imagine Liverpool or Newcastle having the same sense of its own identity?  Brown ale isn't the same in Newcastle as Koelsch is in Koeln...

Guinness has the unfortunate honour of being my "if all else fails" drink, which is a little unfair.  A properly poured pint of the black stuff is better than most English beers, however, I have never tasted it in Ireland.  Whether it's Northern Ireland or the Republic, I am told the Guinness over there is far better than in Britain.  I really can't imagine anyone buying a can of Guinness in the USA really understanding what the beer is about.  I only live 100 miles from Ireland but I feel I have to get on a ferry or aircraft before I'll really know what Guinness is all about.

Actually, I disagree with most of the reviewers.  In a blindfold test, I am sure Bud would one of the easiest of the common UK draught lagers to identify.  However, "kind of beers" it most certainly is not, and it sickens me to see people in UK pubs ordering pints of Bud thinking it is something special when it's not!  I've never even tried genuine USA Bud, because the stuff in the UK is brewed here and can't possibly be the same as the genuine article.

I am not a fan of pilsner beers, but a pint of Budvar is a welcome break from the English town centre lagers.  Not amazing, but well worth seeking out either in the UK or in teh Czech republic - a touch dry but a bit of character and taste that is so lacking in UK lagers.
Overall, just a Scottish version of Caffrey's.  easy to drink, soft, nothing challenging about it.  Try Belhaven Best for something more satisfying.
Bland!  Far too easy to knock back, nothing to make you remember a pint of Caffrey's.  Basically, as easy as drinking milk, nothing at all to make it memorable, and on that note I rate it 5/20.

I can't comment on the bottled variety, but a few pints on draught in Edinburgh were enough to convice me that this is one of the best heavies available on draught in Scottish pubs.  Pints of draught McEwan's 80/- are a quick and pleasant way to get drunk.  On a calmer drinking session, this 80/- deserves a certain respect because frankly it's about the best pint you'll get in Scotland.  Don't let the fact it's gas-powered rather than hand-pumped put you off.  It's like Caffrey's Irish ale, but with an injection of depth, life and soul.  I love McEwans 80 on draught!
Anonymous at best and unpleasant at worst, UK Carlsberg is a Northampton brew that doesn't even come close to matching other chemical lagers like Carling and Fosters.  Very disappointing.

Cool and clear taste, thick white head.  I am just glad that Safeway have seen fit to stock this bier in the UK.  Simply one of my favourite beers.  However, it cannot be stressed enough how impprtant a genuine weissbier glass is when pouring the drink.  Without it, the head can easily vanish.  The only weissbier that ever beat it for me were the locally brewed varieties in Regensburg.  With this beer, I am drinking something that that ranks in my personal shortlist of beers.  The fact I can get it in a UK supermarket is a massive bonus - it's the best weizen easily available in the UK.
Grolsch has got that musty, dry pilsner taste that always puts me off.  Available cheap in the UK, and a good buy compared to the other premium lagers like Kronenbourg and Stella.
Hoegaarden is (in the UK at least) VERY expensive, and although it is EXCELLENT it doesn't justify the typical price tag of 3 a pint.

This is high on my list of beers!  Forget cans, the only way to enjoy it is in a Scottish pub.  It is smooth and easy to drink, and as a Scotsman living in England, Belhaven Best is one beer that I miss!  It's one I always look for when I go back "up the road" for a weekend.
Perfectly reasonable English bitter, but really nothing special.  I would always opt for a hand-pulled pint of Pedigree over a flat glass of Fosters, but that's limited praise.

Basically, Tennent's Lager is as good (if not better) than any of the other cheap lagers in the UK.  People drinking Carling or Fosters in pubs across England don't know what they're missing.  On the other hand, it's a chemically brewed lager and fundamentally it has nothing to recommend it.

I am not a fan of pilsner, but I drank Paulaner Pils for a whole evening and I think this was because it avoids the dry, musty taste we (in Britain) might associate with pilsners like Holsten Pils and Becks.
Munich should be proud.  I have had this on draught quite a few times and I'd rate it as one of the better weissbeirs.

Get a well poured, cold, pint of Foster's and it does a certain job.  However, most English town centre pubs serve it badly, and it suffers as a result.  At its best, it's an easy-to-drink lager that stands above Carlsberg or Carling.

As always, I'll avoid the cliches and the "beer expert" comments.  Frankly, this is an easy-drinking bitter and well worth sampling anywhere near the brewery in Bedford.  Nothing amazing, but perfectly reasonable bitter.

A cloudy beer that I first drank in a random pub on the Strand.  Never had it out of a bottle, only a few times hand pulled, and it has left a lasting impression.  I hate London, but living there would have a few advantages... this beer is one of them.

It's a Scottish ale, with a high alcoholic content!  Dark, sweet, sophisticated ale that makes you wonder how the same brewery can produce McEwans Lager!  Very easy to drink, which, thanks to the 7.3%ABV, always leads to an early, fuzzy night.  One of few British beers that have really caught my attention.
